proof:
With high probability, we have the inequality $|E_C| < \frac{dn}{2} + ne^{-d/3}$, which holds because $|E_C| \le |E_G| = \frac{nd}{2} + o(n)$. From a previous lemma, we also have the bound $|E_K| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}$.
These two bounds allow us to bound the ratio of $|E_C|$ to $|E_K|$ as follows:
$$ \frac{|E_C|}{|E_K|} \le \frac{\frac{dn}{2} + ne^{-d/3}}{\frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}} = \frac{d/2+e^{-d/3}}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}} = 1 + \frac{3e^{-d/3}}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}}. $$
When $d$ is sufficiently large, the fraction $\frac{3}{d/2-2e^{-d/3}}$ is at most $1$. This implies that $|E_C|$ is no more than $(1+e^{-d/3})|E_K|$.
